journalistic.title: The Pine Tree flag: How one symbol at the Capitol riot connects far-right extremism to Christianity [published by the Tow Center]
journalistic.description: A deep dive into the Pine Tree Flag, one of the most prominent symbols seen at the Jan. 6th Capitol Riots, and the political movements, Christian Dominionism and Christian Nationalism, behind it.

journalistic.title: What We Saw at the Capitol Hill Insurrection [published by VICE]
journalistic.description: Nina Berman and I explain the familiar and unfamiliar political symbols seen at the January 6th Capitol Hill Insurrection.
journalistic.image_citation: Image: Robert Nickelsberg via Getty Images

journalistic.title: The Rise of the Thin Blue Line at Trump Rallies [published by the Tow Center]
journalistic.description: I present data about the increasing occurence of the pro-police Thin Blue Line flag at Trump rallies and discuss its significance.
journalistic.image_citation: Image: Mandel Ngan via Getty Images

journalistic.title: This Week in Political Symbols: Pink Pistols, American Guard, NFAC [published by the VizPol team]
journalistic.description: This is the second in our series of weekly posts discussing symbols at recent political events.

journalistic.title: Introducing: This Week in Political Symbols [published by the VizPol team]
journalistic.description: As part of my work on VizPol, an app that helps journalists recognize unfamiliar political symbols I have paid keen attention to symbols appearing on tattoos, hats, t-shirts, flags, and elsewhere, at recent demonstrations and protests across the country. This is the first in our series of weekly posts discussing symbols at recent political events. Our goal is to highlight popular symbols, call for information about new or unfamiliar symbols, and provide journalists with resources on how symbols can (or cannot) be used to glean information about the people and events they are associated with.
journalistic.image_citation: Image: Maranie R. Staab via Getty Images

journalistic.title: Analyzing the Ages of Signatories to the Harper’s Letter and The Objective’s Counter-letter: A Case Study in OSINT Techniques [published by the Tow Center]
journalistic.description: A piece comparing the ages of signatories to "A Letter on Justice and Open Debate" published in Harper's Magazine in July 2020 with the ages of signatories to a statement countering this letter. This also serves as a tutorial on how OSINT techniques can be used to determine someone's age.

journalistic.title: Political Symbols at Demonstrations [published by Columbia Journalism Review]
journalistic.description: In recent weeks, the United States has seen two distinct waves of protests. In April and early May, so-called “Reopen America” protests expressed opposition to  COVID-19 lockdown measures in many states. Currently, demonstrators across the country are protesting against anti-black police brutality, in response to the killing of George Floyd by white police officer Derek Chauvin in Minneapolis. Researchers at the Tow Center and Columbia’s Journalism and Engineering schools have developed a tool called VizPol that can help reporters decipher the symbols and acronyms used by political groups which may be helpful as they report on political actions now and during the election season.
journalistic.image_citation: Image: Jeff Kowalsky/AFP via Getty Images)

journalistic.title: India’s lockdowns and Islamophobia [published by Columbia Journalism Review]
journalistic.description: I wrote about how much of the Indian media's early coverage of COVID-19 in India was Islamophobic and how the government used the crisis to crack down on journalism.

journalistic.title: The Lengthening Arm of Indian Public Diplomacy
journalistic.description: I wrote about how India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has embraced the doctrine of "Public Diplomacy" in his foreign policy much more than his predecessors as part of an application to The Economist.

journalistic.title: What TV stations’ public files tell us about Mike Bloomberg [published by Columbia Journalism Review]
journalistic.description: Sam Thielman and I analyzed where Michael Bloomberg spent his TV advertising budget from data that I collected.
journalistic.image_citation: Image: Screenshot From Michael Bloomberg's "Rebuild America" ad via YouTube.

journalistic.title: Twitter Thread on Protest at Indian Consulate in New York City
journalistic.description: I covered a protest outside the Indian consulate in New York aimed at calling out what demonstrators saw as the complicity of consular officials in promulgating Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist policies.

journalistic.title: On the Indian Diaspora protesting the Citizenship Amendment Act in North America
journalistic.description: I wrote the following rough draft in February 2020 about members of the Indian Diaspora protesting the Citizenship Amendment Act in North America on India’s Republic Day for The Wire in India, but they ultimately decided not to publish it. It is written for an Indian audience.

journalistic.title: Demonstrations on India’s Republic Day in New York, January 26th, 2020: "History has shown us that disenfranchisement is the first step towards genocid"
journalistic.description: My observations from an anti-CAA/NRC demonstration at the Indian Consulate in New York City on Republic Day, January 26th, 2020 and from a pro-CAA/pro-government rally at Times Square later in the day.

journalistic.title: Observations from the Azad Maidan Inquilab Morcha in Mumbai on December 27th, 2019
journalistic.description: My observations from the Inquilab Morcha (Revolutionary Protest) at Azad Maidan in Mumbai on December 27th, 2019.

journalistic.title: Dispatch from the #MumbaikarsAgainstCAB protest at August Kranti Maidan in Mumbai, December 19, 2019
journalistic.description: My observations from the #MumbaikarsAgainstCAB protest at August Kranti Maidan in Mumbai, December 19, 2019.

journalistic.title: When is a frog not a frog? Building a new digital tool to track political symbols [published by Columbia Journalism Review]
journalistic.description: An explanation of our tool, VizPol, that can help reporters decipher the symbols and acronyms used by political groups which may be helpful as they report on political demonstrations.

journalistic.title: What Doesn't Detroit's Courthouse Want You To Know? [published by Gizmodo Media Group's Special Projects Desk now archived on Jezebel]
journalistic.description: Detroit’s 36th District Court put up barriers to scraping their website that make it very difficult for the kind of research that lead to our important story in 2018.

journalistic.title: How a 19th-Century Teenager Sparked a Battle Over Who Owns Our Faces [published by Gizmodo]
journalistic.description: I wrote about the first legal case in America where the Right of Privacy was discussed, at the turn of the 20th century when a young Rochester, NY girl's portrait was used for an ad campaign without her consent. This story caused the City of Rochester to induct the story’s subject into their archive of "Remarkable Rochestrians"

journalistic.title: How I Collected The Data For Our Latest Story On Credit Acceptance [published by Jalopnik]
journalistic.description: A methodology for the data collection and analysis that went into this story.

journalistic.title: How a Subprime Auto Lender Consumed Detroit With Debt and Turned Its Courthouse Into a Collections Agency [published by Jalopnik]
journalistic.description: Ryan Felton and I wrote about the predatory lending practices of Credit Acceptance Corporation, an auto loan maker in Detroit, Michigan.

journalistic.title: The Edit Application
journalistic.description: I wrote a piece about Cornell University's meme page as part of an application to the New York Times' The Edit.

journalistic.title: The Legacy of the Student Assembly [published by The Cornell Daily Sun]
journalistic.description: A friend and I wrote this piece to protest the Cornell Student Assembly's decision to defund Cornell Cinema in 2017.

journalistic.title: In Praise of the Indian Government's response to Leh's Flash Floods
journalistic.description: In High School I would write for a magazine called Spectrum, that some of my peers started. This piece for Spectrum is about the flash floods in Leh, Ladakh in northern India in 2010.
journalistic.image_citation: Image taken from Google Maps

journalistic.title: India's Changing Role in World Politics
journalistic.description: This opinion piece for Spectrum chronicles my beliefs as a 16-year old about the future of India's role in World Politics.

academic.title: VizPol: Real-Time Symbol Recognition for Field Reporting and Image Tagging [Computation + Journalism 2021]
academic.description: A talk about VizPol, a mobile and web-based app that helps photojournalists and political reporters identify unfamiliar graphic symbols at political demonstrations.

academic.title: The Political Visual Literacy App: Real-Time Symbol Recognition for Field Reporting [Computation + Journalism 2020]
academic.description: A paper about VizPol, a mobile and web-based app that helps photojournalists and political reporters identify unfamiliar graphic symbols at political demonstrations.

contributed_to.title: The Tow Center COVID-19 Newsroom Cutback Tracker [published by Columbia Journalism Review]
contributed_to.description: I contributed to the Tow Center's database of cutbacks to newsrooms amidst the COVID-19 pandemic.

contributed_to.title: India had its first ‘WhatsApp election.’ We have a million messages from it [published by Columbia Journalism Review]
contributed_to.description: I helped Priyanjana Bengani with her research investigating closed WhatsApp groups leading up to India's 2019 General Election.

contributed_to.title: Why Democrats Didn't Campaign More on Net Neutrality [published by Gizmodo]
contributed_to.description: I collected data on the net neutrality positions of Democrats campaigning during the 2018 US Midterm Election.

contributed_to.title: Conversations Gone Awry: Detecting Early Signs of Conversational Failure [published in Proceedings of the 56th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL)]
contributed_to.description: I helped Cornell researchers Professor Cristian Danescu-Niculescu-Mizil and Justine Zhang with Natural Language Processing work for their paper.

contributed_to.title: Genome-wide selection component analysis in a wild pedigreed population of the Florida Scrub-Jay.
contributed_to.description: I wrote code that simulates gene-dropping for Cornell researchers Professor Andrew Clark and Nancy Chen's paper.

creative.title: Superficial Sighs
creative.description: You'll have to read this one to know what it's about.
creative.image_citation: Image taken from Washington and Lee University

creative.title: Stevie Nicks and Don Henley
creative.description: An ode to one of my favourite songs.

creative.title: The Thesis Pledge
creative.description: I originally published this as a Twitter thread in response to a New York Times article about how Cornell seniors feel about leaving campus to isolate themselves from the Coronavirus pandemic, but in the interest of ~putting my writing out there~, I decided to publish it here as a standalone piece.

creative.title: Syntactically Speaking
creative.description: I discuss why programming and writing are both so close to my heart and explain why I find them so similar.

creative.title: Through the Lenses Of
creative.description: I wrote this short story as an attempt to mimic the John Cheever's style in The Swimmer.

creative.title: Fight to the Death
creative.description: I wrote this a long time ago as an entry into a 50-word story competition. My piece was chosen as one of the winning entries that were published in the Young Writer's Anthology 2008.
creative.image_citation: Image taken from Ramayana: The Legend of Prince Rama

senior_thesis.title: How Technology Undermined and Clarified Privacy: Camera to Internet
senior_thesis.description: In my senior thesis I try and conceptualize privacy in term's of technology's relationship with it. I construct a lens through which to think about the privacy implications of any new technology. I use this lens to discuss the portable Camera of the late 19th century, the Telephone of the early 20th century, the GPS of the mid-20th century and the Internet. I worked on this for the whole of my senior year as an undergraduate.
senior_thesis.image_citation: Image taken from Max Hoffman's blog (Jeremy Bentham's Panopticon, 18th c.)

undergraduate_essays.title: A reading of Jameson’s Archaeologies of the Future and Du Bois’ The Comet from the perspective of Barthes’ project in Empire of Signs
undergraduate_essays.description: I talk about these three authors' views on the notion of an "emptiness of language". I wrote this essay for my class on Science Fiction and the Value of Utopia/Dystopia.

undergraduate_essays.title: Politics as a Device used to underscore the Importance of the Individual Artist in Nabokov’ s Work
undergraduate_essays.description: By pinpointing apparent contradictions in Nabokov's work I discuss how in reality these are deliberate devices Nabokov employs to comment on the detrimental effect totalitarian regimes have on individual artistic expression. I wrote this essay for my class on Reading Nabokov.

undergraduate_essays.title: An Examination of the extent to which Derek Walcott is divided in his poetics, and what this does for his poetics, through a discussion of "Prelude", "Bleecker Street, Summer" and "The Castaway" by Walcott and "Ode To Autumn" by John Keats
undergraduate_essays.description: I discuss Derek Walcott's deep cognitive dissonance about the English literary tradition. He is inspired by it yet pained by the oppression its creators wrought upon his people. I wrote this essay for my class on Contemporary World Literature.

undergraduate_essays.title: I Propose that Consciousness is aimed at an Organism's Survival
undergraduate_essays.description: I wrote this essay for my class on Minds and Machines.
undergraduate_essays.image_citation: Image taken from Wikipedia (Robert Fludd's Representation of Consciousness, 17th c.)

undergraduate_essays.title: Thought May Just be Organizing Representations
undergraduate_essays.description: I discuss the Hilary Putnam's Computational Theory of Mind offering personal anecdotes as to why I think there might be some validity to it. I wrote this essay for my class on Minds and Machines.

undergraduate_essays.title: A Comparison and Contrast of Early Daoist Inner Cultivation Practices with the Meditation Practices of Zen Master Hakuin
undergraduate_essays.description: By comparing Daoist and Zen meditation practices I attempt to understand what kinds of people would be attracted to each of these religious traditions. I wrote this essay for my class on Asian Religions.

undergraduate_essays.title: Distance between Partners as a Direct Consequence of State of Flux they are in, in Jhumpa Lahiri's Interpreter of Maladies
undergraduate_essays.description: I discuss the different types of distance between different sets of partners in Lahiri's short stories. I wrote this essay for my class on Asian American Literature.

undergraduate_essays.title: An Examination of Marx’s Response to the Liberal Conception of Freedom
undergraduate_essays.description: In this essay I discuss Marx's ideas about the differences between liberty for the individual and collective liberty. I wrote this essay for my class on Modern Political Theory.

undergraduate_essays.title: How did approaches to knowledge of nature relate to, or involve, ideas about God and the divine in the period from Greek antiquity to the end of the seventeenth century?
undergraduate_essays.description: I attempt to understand the changing conception of God or the "Demiurge" in Science or "Natural Philosophy" from Greek antiquity to the end of the seventeenth centuty CE. I wrote this essay for my class on the History of Science from Galileo to Newton.
undergraduate_essays.image_citation: Image taken from Pinterest (Gnostic conception of Demiurge)

undergraduate_essays.title: Haraway's Cyborg Manifesto in the context of Moore's "No Woman Born" and Le Guin's Left Hand of Darkness
undergraduate_essays.description: I respond to: Discuss Haraway's Cyborg Manifesto in the context of C.L Moore's "No Woman Born" and Le Guin's Left Hand of Darkness. What does Haraway's articulation of the cyborg contribute to the fictional readings? Think in terms of technology, identity, and Haraway's suggestions for political identification and resistance. I wrote this essay for my Freshman Writing Seminar on Gender Politics and Science Fiction.
undergraduate_essays.image_citation: Image taken from Sedef's Feminist Science Fiction Blog

undergraduate_essays.title: A Post Gender World
undergraduate_essays.description: Using theoretical work by Anne Fausto-Sterling and Donna Haraway, and fiction by Ursula K. Le Guin and C.L. Moore I conceptualize what a post-gender world might look like. I wrote this essay for my Freshman Writing Seminar on Gender Politics and Science Fiction.
undergraduate_essays.image_citation: Image taken from NYTimes "What Biracial People Know", March 5, 2017

travel.title: American Southwest
travel.description: An account of my trip to Santa Fe, New Mexico and Zion, Utah with my college roommates.

travel.title: Tamil Nadu, India
travel.description: An account of my "temple tour" of Tamil Nadu with my family.
